div.p:
Dinuclear Pd(II) halides that contain bridging π-conjugated groups,
trans
,
trans
-[(PR
3
)
2
(X)Pd–Y–Pd(X)(PR
3
)
2
] (X = Br; YH
2
= terpyridine, fluorenone, benzil, benzthiadiazole), were prepared by the oxidative addition of corresponding dihalo π-conjugated reagents to [Pd(styrene)(PR
3
)
2
]. Similar reactions involving dihalobenzil, dihalobithiophene, or dihaloterthiophene afforded dinuclear Pt(II) halides containing bridging π-conjugated groups. Additionally, when the dihalosilole derivatives {2,5-dibromo-1,1-dimethyl (or diphenyl)-3,4-diphenylsilole} reacted with [Pd(styrene)(PR
3
)
2
], mono or dinuclear Pd(II) complexes bearing a dimethyl (or diphenyl)-3,4-diphenylsilole group were obtained. π-Conjugation extension reactions of dinuclear bithiophene-bridged Pd(II) halides with HC≡C–R {R = SiPh
3
, C(O)OMe} in the presence of CuI and HNEt
2
led to the unexpected formation of bis(acetylide) Pd(II) complexes of the form, [Pd(C≡C–R)
2
(PR
3
)
2
] and bithiophene. In contrast, treatment of the dinuclear Pd(II) halides with two equiv of organic isocyanide resulted in isocyanide insertion into the Pd − C bonds to afford π-conjugation-extended dinuclear Pd(II) compounds bearing a π-conjugated moiety.
Keywords:

Dinuclear group 10 metal complexes possessing a bridging π-conjugated group are known to act as catalytic intermediates or potential precursors for electronically or optically useful materials [
1–4
]. Several research groups have previously prepared complexes with bridging aryl or thienyl groups by oxidative addition of dihaloaryl or dihalothienyl compounds to zero-valent group 10 metal complexes [
5–13
]. Some diplatinum thienyl or phenylene compounds have also been prepared by reaction of bis(stannyl) thiophene or -phenylene with olefin-coordinated platinum dichloride [
14
,
15
]. Despite their potential applications in the synthesis of electronic and optical materials, reports of the syntheses of dinuclear group 10 metal complexes containing π-conjugated bridging groups are still limited. In this work, we report the synthesis of dinuclear Pd(II) halides with a variety of π-conjugated bridging groups by the oxidative addition of dihaloaryl or heterocyclic compounds (X–Y–X =
I
–
VI
,
Chart 1
). In addition, we attempted to extend the π-conjugation system of the dinuclear Pd(II) complexes by alkyne- or isocyanide-insertion into the Pd–C bond, with an expectation to give π-conjugated electronic materials.

Complexes

–
6

1

3
was obtained as a crystal suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis.

Figure 1
shows the molecular structure of
3

trans

···Pd
2

div.p:
Scheme 3.
Synthesis of Pd(II) complexes with silole or bridged silole.

Scheme 3.
Synthesis of Pd(II) complexes with silole or bridged silole.

The double oxidative addition of dihaloaryl compounds is the most convenient method for the preparation of dinuclear transition–metal complexes bearing a bridging aryl moiety. Most dinucelar complexes have been prepared by reactions of dihaloaryl compounds with [ML
4
] (M = Pd or Pt; L = PPh
3
), but these oxidative addition reactions require high-temperature conditions (30–120 °C), depending on the transition metal [
6
,
8
,
13
]. In contrast, a few cases reported that dihalo π-conjugated (including thiophene) compounds react with [Pd(PPh
3
)
4
] or [Pd(dba)
2
] at room temperature to afford dinuclear Pd(II) compounds bearing a π-conjugated spacer [
9
,
11
,
12
]. Our room temperature reactions of dihalo π-conjugated compounds or thiophene analogs using metal(0) olefin compounds are more facile than those using [ML
4
] compounds; the latter reactions require higher temperatures to afford M(0) compound. In addition, the dinuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) compounds formed could be identified by the integration ratio of the bridging spacer group compared with the supporting phosphine ligands as well as one singlet in
31
P{
1
H} NMR spectra, which indicates a symmetric dinuclear form. Consequently, the syntheses of various dinuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) complexes bearing a bridging π-conjugated moiety in
Schemes 1–3
could provide precursors or useful synthetic tools for electronic or self-assembled compounds.

We attempted to extend the π-conjugation of the dinuclear Pd(II) complexes by using alkynes (HC≡C–R; R = SiPh
3
, C(O)OMe) in the presence of CuI and Et
2
NH. We treated dinuclear bithiophene-bridged Pd(II) halides with two equiv of HC≡C–SiPh
3
. Rather than the expected π-conjugated extended products (Equation 1 of
Figure 4
), a mixture of the bis(acetylide) Pd(II) complex and a starting material was obtained. In contrast, when the same compound was treated with an excess of HC≡C–SiPh
3
, it was completely converted to the bis(acetylide) Pd(II) complex,
trans
-[Pd(C≡C–SiPh
3
)
2
(PMe
3
)
2
] (
16
) (
Scheme 4
). In addition, the reaction employing HC≡C–C(O)OMe also produced the bis(acetylide) Pd(II) complex
trans
-[Pd{C≡C–C(O)OMe}
2
(PMe
3
)
2
] (
17
) (Equation 1 in
Scheme 4
). In these reactions, the organic bithiophene as a side product is soluble in excess of hexane and readily removed during recrystallization. Other possible bithiophene R–C
4
H
2
S–C
4
H
2
S–R (R = C≡C–SiPh
3
) (
18
), which may be formed by reductive elimination from the dinuclear compound, could also be prepared independently by treating bithiophene bromide with H–C≡C–SiPh
3
(Equation 2 in
Scheme 4
).

–1
correspond to the ν(C≡C) stretch. Complex

Figure 2
. An asymmetric unit contains one half of the molecule with the Pd metal at the crystallographic center of symmetry, and therefore, this crystal has a
Z
value of 1 instead of 2.

Scheme 5.
Synthesis of Pd(II) bis(acetylide) complexes.

In contrast with the aforementioned alkyne coupling, 2 equivalent of isocyanide (
n
-butyl and 2,6-dimethylphenyl isocyanide) was inserted into both Pd–C bonds of the dinuclear Pd(II) halides (
2
,
6
,
10
and
12
) to afford conjugation-extended compounds (
Scheme 6
). The reaction mixtures of
2
,
6
and
10
changed color rapidly, indicating instant isocyanide insertion. However, the reaction involving
12
, which has a bridging thiophene group, required mild heating because of its poor solubility in organic solvents. The IR spectra of the products (complexes
20
–
23
) exhibited a new C = N stretching band at 1,557–1,605 cm
–1
, supporting the isocyanide insertion. The exact integral ratios of the aryl or alkyl peaks in the
1
H NMR spectra of
20
–
23
are strongly indicative of isocyanide insertion into both Pd–C bonds. The
31
P{
1
H} spectra of the complexes show a singlet, consistent with their symmetric structures. Although many cases [
29–42
] of isocyanide insertion into the Pd–C or Pt–C bonds of mononuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) complexes are currently known, those involving dinuclear complexes are still rare [
4
,
7
,
10
,
11
,
14
b].

Young-Sung
Han
,
Kang-Yeoun
Jung
,
Yong-Joo

,
Gang Min
Lee
&
Soon W.
Lee

div.p:
Scheme 6.
Reactions of dinuclear Pd(II) complexes with organic isocyanides.

Scheme 6.
Reactions of dinuclear Pd(II) complexes with organic isocyanides.

We prepared a series of dinuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) halides bearing π-conjugated moieties by oxidative addition of π-conjugated organic dihalides to bis(phosphine) styrene complexes [M(styrene)L
2
]. Similarly, we prepared mono- or dinuclear Pd(II) halides bearing a five-membered silole group. The double oxidative additions of dihalo-organic compounds to M(olefin)L
2
are better synthetic tools to afford various dinuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) dihalides bearing π-conjugated moieties than analogous reactions using ML
4
compounds; the latter reactions require higher temperatures to produce electronically unsaturated metal(0) compound.

Attempts to extend the π-conjugation of dinuclear Pd(II) or Pt(II) halides bearing aryl moieties using alkynes were unsuccessful. However, similar reactions of bis(thiophene)-bridged Pd(II) halides using an alkyne only led to the formation of Pd(II) bis(acetylides) and bithiophene, suggesting that the Pd–thienyl bond is weaker than the Pd–aryl bond. In contrast, treatments of dinuclear Pd(II) halides with organic isocyanides induced isocyanide insertion into both Pd–C bonds to afford conjugation-extended compounds.
